body_html:
To fit it into how pytorch works currently, we could represent block-sparse tensors as 4D COO tensors, where the first two dimensions are sparse and the last two are dense. Essentially the first two dimensions indicate which "block of the grid" we're in, and the last two dimensions are the dense pieces of the matrix. I'm assuming the blocks are all the same size.

But it might be nicer to have a user-facing block sparse API
